pullRequest.body:
As mentioned in #15522, the documentation uses heavily the wording "ordinal approximation", which suggests that ordinals are approximated. This PR changes it to "ordinal-indexed approximation" and highlights the indexed nature of ordinals in various places. It also fixes some apparent then vs than errors.

I appreciate any suggestions to further improve the documentation and hints for spelling mistakes.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.
Oh, I'm sorry! I thought this was my PR for a sec...
I appreciate the help anyway!
maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.
bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11032668298/job/30642098000)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11032668298/job/30642097324)
These new docstrings are definitely clearer. I've left a few spell-checking remarks as well as more opinionated suggestions (which all apply dually to `gfpApprox`).

I'd write down the recursive definition here in plaintext, something like
```text
The ordinal-indexed sequence of fixed point approximations `f^[a] x` is defined so that `f^[0] x = x` and `f^[a] x = ‚®Ü b < a, f (f^[a] x)`.
```
You can use `lfpApprox` directly instead of `f^[a]` if you find that clearer.

Also, you wrote down "approximantion" instead of "approximation".

I decided against `f^[a]` as (1) mathlib only offers this notation for natural numbers, (2) we would have this notation twice in the file with different semantics - which seems confusing to me.

Otherwise, I split your suggestion into two sentences, so that it is hopefully a bit nicer to read.
Yeah, this new docstring is much better.

```suggestion
/-- The approximations of the least fixed point stabilize at a fixed point of `f`
```
I don't think it's necessary to reiterate that we're talking about ordinals throughout the entire file.

```suggestion
/-- There are distinct indices smaller than the successor of the domain's cardinal yielding the same value
```
It's not the indices that have the same value, but rather the values associated to those indices that are equal.

```suggestion
/-- If there are distinct indices yielding equal values then
  every value at indices succeeding the smaller index is a fixed point -/
```

```suggestion
/-- A fixed point of f is reached at the successor of the domain's cardinality -/
```
This isn't an ordinal successor, but rather a cardinal one!
Oooops. I may have thought about a successor ordinal used in the papers, which we could avoid using because Lean is not based on ZFC.
Also, I reordered the sentence so it is not passive any more.

```suggestion
/-- Every value of the ordinal-indexed approximation is less or equal than every fixed point of `f`
```

```suggestion
/-- The least fixed point of f is reached at the successor
  of the domain's cardinality -/
```
I'd argue this theorem says something slightly distinct, which is that the approximants of `‚ä•` specifically converge at the least fixed point.
I rephrased that sentence to include the convergence at the successor starting from `‚ä•`.

```suggestion
/-- Some approximation of the least fixed point is the least fixed point. -/
```

```suggestion
an initial value `x`. It is defined in such a way that we have `lfpApprox 0 x = x` and
`lfpApprox a x = ‚®Ü b < a, f (lfpApprox b x)`. -/
```
Please don't indent docstrings

```suggestion
every value at indices succeeding the smaller index is a fixed point -/
```

```suggestion
/-- There are distinct indices smaller than the successor of the cardinality of the domain
```

```suggestion
/-- If the sequence of ordinal-indexed approximations takes a value twice,
then it actually stabilised at that value. -/
```
What do you think?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - doc: Improve documentation of ordinal-indexed approximations
